question: Can we give a mechanistically intelligible explanation of how AZC legality fields suppress parts of the B grammar without selection, branching, or semantics - at the instruction class level?
closure_statement: AZC does not modify B's grammar; it shortens the reachable language by restricting vocabulary availability. The 49-class grammar and 17 forbidden transitions are universal. When AZC provides a legality field, 6 of 9 hazard-involved classes have reduced effective membership because their MIDDLEs become unavailable. The 3 atomic hazard classes remain fully active regardless of AZC context.

atomic.behavior: Always fully available - universal hazard enforcement

mechanism.step_1: AZC provides ambient legality field (vocabulary availability)
mechanism.step_2: 77% of MIDDLEs restricted to specific AZC folios
mechanism.step_3: Decomposable hazard classes lose effective membership

interpretation.what_azc_does: Restricts vocabulary availability without modifying grammar
interpretation.what_azc_does_not_do: Selection, branching, semantic control, numeric encoding
interpretation.result: Same grammar everywhere, different reachable parts

pipeline_completion.AZC: Projects them into position-indexed legality fields
pipeline_completion.B: Executes within the shrinking reachable language
